Award.AbstractNarration:
Commutative Algebra is a ubiquitous mathematical subject whose techniques and results are utilized in Algebraic Geometry, Number Theory, and Representation Theory. Morgantown Algebra Days is a Commutative Algebra conference which is to take place at West Virginia University on the weekend of April 13-14, 2019. The main objective of the conference is to showcase new mathematical trends to a large group of mathematicians specializing in the subject of Commutative Algebra. Morgantown Algebra Days will feature eight research talks and poster session allowing for younger mathematicians to present their research.
The website for the conference is https://www.math.wvu.edu/mad2019/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Morgantown Algebra Days was a mathematical research conference which took place on the weekend of April 13-14, 2019 at West Virginia University. The purpose of the conference was to showcase new mathematical trends in the subject of Commutative Algebra to a large group of mathematicians. This objective was accomplished by featuring eight research talks by experts in Commutative Algebra and by hosting a poster session in which seventeen graduate students were able to display and discuss their results with members of the community.  Commutative Algebra is an active area of research with a vibrant community of researchers who continue to provide novel techniques for those new or interested to the subject to incorporate into their own investigations. Furthermore, Commutative Algebra is relevant to the study of many mathematical subjects. Therefore,  Morgantown Algebra Days accomplished an important task by informing mathematicians of current trends pertaining to this subject.


Morgantown Algebra Days featured a diverse group of participants and speakers and therefore successfully promoted diversity in mathematics. Moreover, the region surrounding Morgantown, West Virginia has historically lacked conferences specializing in Commutative Algebra and Morgantown Algebra Days provided a much desired opportunity for faculty and graduate students nearby to come together, exchange ideas, and collaborate.
